image.altText: Varroa mite nestled on a bee, with a blue circle identifying it on the body

props.synopsis: Australia has decided it is no longer technically feasible to eradicate varroa mite and will move to management of the pest.

title.children: Australia abandons efforts to eradicate deadly parasite varroa mite after 15 months

image.altText: A man with sunglasses stands on the beach with his arms folded.

props.synopsis: The search for fugitive gunman Stanley Turvey is over after police shot him dead at Ardmona, near the northern Victorian city of Shepparton.

title.children: Fugitive Stanley Turvey shot dead by police in northern Victoria after three-day manhunt

image.altText: Side shot of man being led by police

props.synopsis: When gangland figure Alen Moradian was shot in an underground car park it locked down a busy Sydney suburb for hours, as two cars were found burnt out and a manhunt began.

title.children: Two charged over 'well-planned' daylight execution that shut parts of Bondi Junction for hours

image.altText: Sector commander stands facing a controlled burn

props.synopsis: A day after El Niño was formally declared by the Bureau of Meteorology, fire bans are in place as hot and dry conditions are forecast across New South Wales.

title.children: 'Extreme' fire danger warnings for Sydney, Hunter regions as record hot weather persists

image.altText: Burnt timber as far as the mountain horizon five months after fire and green regrowth on trees

props.synopsis: The CSIRO releases guide to show businesses how to measure natural assets such as clean air, water, soil, and living things, and incorporate them into their financial books.

title.children: CSIRO says we need to stop 'catastrophic decline' in our natural systems, releases Natural Capital Handbook for Australian businesses

image.altText: close up of packets of lamb cutlets on Coles shelf

props.synopsis: With some lambs and sheep selling for as little as $2 a head, why are consumers only just starting to see minor price cuts at the supermarket?

title.children: Why are consumers missing out as lamb prices plummet at the saleyards?

image.altText: Two police officers arresting a man with grey hair

props.synopsis: A 68-year-old man is expected to be extradited from Victoria to the ACT, after being arrested over the Canberra cold case killing of Irma Palasics.

title.children: Man arrested in Melbourne over the 1999 murder of Canberra woman Irma Palasics

image.altText: Two forensics officers with their backs facing the camera and police tape behind them.

props.synopsis: Police allege six teenagers forced their way inside a home at Merewether before stabbing a man and a woman.

title.children: Boy, 14, charged with attempted murder after alleged Newcastle home invasion, stabbing

image.altText: A mural featuring the image of a man in a turban

props.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says Australia has raised concerns with India about a fatal shooting in Canada, which that country has blamed on India-backed agents.

title.children: Australia raises concerns with India over allegations it sent assassins to kill Sikh leader in Canada

image.altText: Image from Twitter of New York Times ad.

props.synopsis: Over 200 climate scientists have taken out a full-page ad in the New York Times calling out Australia's "climate annihilation", while Fijian activists impacted by rising sea levels urge Canberra to do more.

title.children: Scientists take out full-page New York Times ad calling on Australia to end ‘climate annihilation’

image.altText: Paul has dark hair and a beard and wears a blue jacket with white flowers on his lapel and a patterned bowtie

props.synopsis: Police have charged an 18-year-old Belmont man with the murder of 40-year-old Paul Grapsas, whose body was found hours after he left home for a late-night dog walk last Thursday.

title.children: Police charge 18-year-old man with murder of Geelong father Paul Grapsas

image.altText: Woman running a marathon at sunset

props.synopsis: We know the impact hot weather can have on the environment, but what does it do to your body?

title.children: How heatwaves impact your body

image.altText: weatherboard two storey home with mesh security fence around it with Northern Rivers Reconstruction Corporation signage

props.synopsis: The state budget did not deliver a significant increase to the Northern Rivers buyback scheme, with Labor MP for Lismore admitting she'd hoped for more.

title.children: Flood-hit communities banking on $700m helping hand say they've been 'short-changed' in watered-down budget

image.altText: Two firefighter stand holding a house and spraying water onto a building that is engulfed in bright orange flames.

props.synopsis: A Russian drone strike destroys humanitarian aid supplies in the western Ukranian city of Lviv, according to officials.

title.children: Charity donations destined for 600 Ukrainian families destroyed in drone strike

image.altText: Aerial of the Maules Creek Mine

props.synopsis: A Boggabri coal worker has told a Sydney court there was nowhere for the shock wave to go as he was caught unaware from a blast at nearby Maules Creek.

title.children: Mine worker tells court of long lasting effects after being caught 'out in the open' during Maules Creek blast

image.altText: Woman curling up on bed while clutching her stomach

props.synopsis: One in seven women aged between 44 and 49 live with the chronic disease as more are getting diagnosed early, a new report finds.

title.children: Endometriosis hospitalisation rate almost doubles, with 20-24 age group seeing the biggest increase, report shows

image.altText: David Porecki sings the national anthem

props.synopsis: The Wallabies line-out fired against Fiji, with hooker Dave Porecki leading the World Cup for accuracy, but Wales are set to provide a sterner set-piece test.

title.children: 'Every game is do-or-die': Wallabies need to fire against Wales

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin with his wife and daughter

props.synopsis: When Prigozhin staged a mutiny against Putin's military, he effectively signed his own death warrant. But what happens to his wife and children?

title.children: Before he died in a fiery crash, Prigozhin's family lived a life of opulence. Now they have a choice

image.altText: An aerial view of green sea water.

props.synopsis: An unusually dense plankton bloom off the eastern coast of Thailand is creating an aquatic "dead zone".

title.children: Extreme plankton bloom creates marine 'dead zone' off eastern Thailand

image.altText: Geonet quake

props.synopsis: A magnitude-6 earthquake strikes near Geraldine in the centre of New Zealand's South Island.

title.children: New Zealand hit by magnitude-6 earthquake, no serious damage reported

image.altText: Two army personnel standing outside a brick home.

props.synopsis: The pilot, who has not been identified by the Marine Corps, did not have serious injuries and has been discharged from the hospital.

title.children: Pilot of downed F-35 fighter jet parachuted safely into a backyard

image.altText: An emotional Bryan Beattie standing with family and friends outside court

props.synopsis: A Supreme Court judge has found a 14-year-old boy not guilty of murder, despite his involvement in a frenzied gang attack that claimed the life of a teenager in Melbourne's north last year.

title.children: Father wipes away tears after 14yo involved in fatal attack on Declan Cutler found not guilty of murder

image.altText: A smartphone with an Airbnb logo on it in front of the same logo being projected on a screen.

props.synopsis: Short-stay rental platforms, such as Airbnb and Stayz, will face a 7.5 per cent levy from 2025, the Victorian government says.

title.children: Short-stay tax, social housing rebuild announced in Victorian policy roadmap

image.altText: Man smiling at camera, basketball court behind

props.synopsis: Youth crime has dominated headlines in Queensland for months. But a Sunshine Coast man has a plan to help break the cycle — and he's putting his money where his mouth is.

title.children: Counsellor pours life savings into free centre helping troubled teens reconnect and 'give back' to community

image.altText: Headshots of Prince William, PennyWong and Volodomyr Zelenskyy

props.synopsis: World leaders converge in New York City for the biggest gathering of global decision-makers since COVID. Here are some takeaways from day one of this year's UN General Assembly meeting.

title.children: 'Our world is becoming unhinged': Here's what happened on day one of the UN's big annual meeting

image.altText: Joe Biden stands at a podium and speaks into two microphones. He's wearing a blue jacket and a striped tie.

props.synopsis: The Republican-led committee alleges Joe Biden profited from his son's business dealings while serving as vice president, which he denies.

title.children: US House panel sets date for first Biden impeachment inquiry hearing

image.altText: A building with a for sale sign on the window

props.synopsis: The Qantas CEO is ordered into mediation with the workers' union, the Senate holds a hearing into regional bank closures by major banks, and the ASX is in negative territory this afternoon.

title.children: Qantas CEO ordered into mediation with Transport Workers' Union, Senate inquiry into bank closures, ASX down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mr Elliott says ANZ is the largest bank to Australia's resources sector (iron ore, gold, lithium, you name it). But in terms of thermal coal, ANZ hasn't conducted any new lending to thermal coal projects for half a dozen years. He said ANZ still has an exposure to thermal coal, but that exposure is winding down over time. He said the bank decided years ago that the future risk profile for thermal coal didn't look good, because when thinking about the long-term, large amounts of financing, the risks around extracting and processing, and sovereign risk, "we couldn't really make sensible risk-based decisions by continuing in that sector." "We made this very obvious to our customers," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ says the risk profile of thermal coal projects is not good

children.content: Mr Elliott says ANZ is the largest bank to Australia's resources sector (iron ore, gold, lithium, you name it).
But in terms of thermal coal, ANZ hasn't conducted any new lending to thermal coal projects for half a dozen years.
He said ANZ still has an exposure to thermal coal, but that exposure is winding down over time.

He said the bank decided years ago that the future risk profile for thermal coal didn't look good, because when thinking about the long-term, large amounts of financing, the risks around extracting and processing, and sovereign risk, "we couldn't really make sensible risk-based decisions by continuing in that sector."
"We made this very obvious to our customers," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Shayne Elliott, ANZ chief executive, has joined the inquiry. He starts by talking about how different ANZ's business is, compared to the other big three. He's says according to the bank's research, customers in all age brackets say they find digital banking convenient and they like it. He says that includes customers in the over 65 category. He says customers who are hard of hearing also say they enjoy digital banking. This feels like it runs counter to some of the things Finance Sector Union representatives were saying a little earlier. The FSU reps said many older customers really struggled with mobile phone apps, and online banking, and were left feeling outcast by the pace of technological change.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ chief executive joins the inquiry

children.content: Shayne Elliott, ANZ chief executive, has joined the inquiry.
He starts by talking about how different ANZ's business is, compared to the other big three.
He's says according to the bank's research, customers in all age brackets say they find digital banking convenient and they like it. He says that includes customers in the over 65 category.
He says customers who are hard of hearing also say they enjoy digital banking.
This feels like it runs counter to some of the things Finance Sector Union representatives were saying a little earlier.
The FSU reps said many older customers really struggled with mobile phone apps, and online banking, and were left feeling outcast by the pace of technological change.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Finance Sector Union is up now. Myrna Ellery, a member of the Finance Sector Union, says she worked as a banker for 25 years as a customer service specialist in a retail environment, most recently 10 years with NAB. She's just talked about the impact that bank closures have on staff and the local community, saying it can be "devastating" for rural communities. "Staff are often given very little notice when their bank is about to close," she said. She's just described in detail how bank staff can be caught in a Catch-22 situation that leads to their branches being closed. "Frontline branch staff in most banks have targets imposed on them to migrate customers to digital banking options. "The friendly concierge at the front door is there to guide customers to digital options to deter them from getting to a teller's station. She says branch staff have KPIs and targets imposed on them for migrating customers away from interactions with physical staff and towards digital options, and if you're good at your job then you're eventually doing yourself out of a job, because the numbers will show that staff are less and less required. "The irony of this is that you are damned if you do and damned if you don't," she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Banks try to stop customers dealing with physical staff

children.content: The Finance Sector Union is up now.
Myrna Ellery, a member of the Finance Sector Union, says she worked as a banker for 25 years as a customer service specialist in a retail environment, most recently 10 years with NAB.
She's just talked about the impact that bank closures have on staff and the local community, saying it can be "devastating" for rural communities.
"Staff are often given very little notice when their bank is about to close," she said.
She's just described in detail how bank staff can be caught in a Catch-22 situation that leads to their branches being closed.
"Frontline branch staff in most banks have targets imposed on them to migrate customers to digital banking options.
"The friendly concierge at the front door is there to guide customers to digital options to deter them from getting to a teller's station.

She says branch staff have KPIs and targets imposed on them for migrating customers away from interactions with physical staff and towards digital options, and if you're good at your job then you're eventually doing yourself out of a job, because the numbers will show that staff are less and less required.
"The irony of this is that you are damned if you do and damned if you don't," she said.

image.altText: Peter Dutton wearing black glasses standing in front of a blurry australian flag looking straight toward the camera

props.synopsis: Australia quietly cancels plans to buy reconnaissance drones used by China and Russia under a $1 billion Navy project controversially approved just days before last year's election by then defence minister Peter Dutton.

title.children: Dutton dubs Labor scrapping billion-dollar military drone plan 'contemptible'

image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands in a courtyard at parliament house.

props.synopsis: New economic forecasts are painting a bleak picture for the world's economy in 2024, dragged down by persistent inflation and ongoing problems in China.

title.children: World economy forecast to slow further, dragged down by high inflation and a troubled China

image.altText: Milk on supermarket shelf showing price

props.synopsis: As consumers adjust to the impact of the rising cost of living, Coles has increased its own-brand milk price by 10 cents per litre. But for farmers, it feels like redemption.

title.children: Why Coles has 'reluctantly' raised the price of its milk this week

image.altText: A group of women arrive at a hotel, surrounded by media.

props.synopsis: Spain's secretary for sport says 'we looked ridiculous as a nation', as the country's women's football team attends training camp despite an ongoing boycott.

title.children: 'We were obligated to come': Stony-faced Spanish stars forced to attend training despite ongoing boycott

image.altText: a person in an Akubra hat silhouetted against an Indigenous flag

props.synopsis: A far-right US media figure who has made racist attacks on Indigenous Australians spoke at a conservative conference chaired by leading No campaigner Warren Mundine.

title.children: Far-right US podcaster spoke at conservative conference chaired by Warren Mundine

image.altText: A couple has their wedding photograph taken underwater.

props.synopsis: A plunge in the number of Chinese couples willing to tie the knot is hurting the marriage industry and worrying officials trying to revive marriage and birth rates.

title.children: 'Some of my clients have actually separated': Marriage woes hit once-lavish Chinese wedding industry
